channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Dueling Narratives of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
item.description: To most Israeli Jews, the recent violence is a spate of random attacks against innocents. Palestinians see it as excessive force against not only attackers but anyone who looks like them.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman watched an Israeli boy lighting candles at the site of a stabbing attack in Jerusalem this month.

item.title: News Analysis: White House Quiet on South China Sea Patrol That Beijing Calls ‘Provocation’
item.description: Even as it authorized the warship’s route near disputed islands, the administration played down the incident to avoid escalating conflict with China.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Dispute With David Cameron Opens New Challenge to House of Lords
item.description: After the House of Lords derailed planned cuts to social welfare programs, the British prime minister announced a review of the chamber’s powers.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Netanyahu Quiets Deputy Who Said She Dreamed of Israeli Flag Over Jerusalem Holy Site
item.description: The prime minister is under fire for not controlling his governing coalition as archconservatives take provocative stands amid a wave of knife attacks by Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel attending a memorial ceremony on Monday in Jerusalem for the 20th anniversary of the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Economist Responds to Critics of His Proposal to Let Men Share a Wife
item.description: Xie Zuoshi says he doesn’t think the arrangement has much chance of actually becoming legal, but he defends his reasoning.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parents gathered at a “marriage market” at the Temple of Heaven in Beijing to seek spouses for their children. Xie Zuoshi, an economics professor, supports more flexible marital arrangements to address the surplus of bachelors.

item.title: Taliban Complicate Effort to Aid Afghans After Quake
item.description: For months, residents have been caught between the Taliban, militias and government forces; a devastating earthquake is adding to the misery.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: A damaged house in Mingora, Pakistan, the main town of the Swat Valley, on Tuesday, a day after a deadly earthquake hit the area.

item.title: How Britain’s House of Lords Blocked David Cameron’s Cut in Tax Credits
item.description: As the upper chamber in Parliament, once a preserve of the nobility, has swelled with left-leaning members, legislation from Mr. Cameron’s Conservative Party has been thwarted.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:credit: Parliamentary Recording Unit, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from a video shows the House of Lords gathering on Monday for a debate on the government's plans to cut tax credits for low-income workers and people with children.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Cartoon: Chappatte on Keeping U.S. Troops in Afghanistan
item.description: America’s search for an exit from Afghanistan continues.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Europe Is Spying on You
item.description: A number of governments risk undermining democracy while pretending to protect it.
item.dc:creator: NILS MUIZNIEKS

item.title: Semyonovka Journal: Ukraine Ban on Russian Symbols Fuels Fight Over National Identity
item.description: Older Ukrainians seeking to preserve the past resist a law pushed through Parliament that requires the removal of all Communist-era names and symbols.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Lenin, which once stood in the town's Red Square, in its new home in a leafy park in Semyonovka, Ukraine. "We want to preserve this small corner of Soviet history,” Ivan M. Papchenko, right, the local Communist Party chief, said of the statue.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe Turns Down Confucius Peace Prize
item.description: A Zimbabwean news organization reported that Mr. Mugabe decided to reject the prize after learning that it had nothing to do with the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Turkey Confirms Strikes Against Kurdish Militias in Syria
item.description: The confirmation of the strikes adds a new level of complexity to the United States’ struggle to craft a coherent strategy to fight the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says Yemen Hospital Is Destroyed
item.description: The site was struck multiple times by warplanes belonging to the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia, forcing evacuations, the group said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: In Cuba, an Abundance of Love but a Lack of Babies
item.description: An aging population, a scarcity of jobs and a liberal abortion policy add to a demographic crisis in Cuba, where many say they cannot afford to have a child.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pregnant woman waiting outside a hospital in Havana. Cuba's low birthrate is a problem more common to rich, industrialized nations.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese State Planning Meets ‘Schoolhouse Rock!’ in New Video
item.description: A new video has brought the world’s biggest publicity machine to a new era: 1973.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ai Weiwei Setting Up Lego Collection Points After Company Refuses His Order
item.description: The Chinese artist and dissident said that the Lego Group had rejected an order for several million Lego bricks that would have been used to create works for an exhibition titled “Andy Warhol | Ai Weiwei,” scheduled to open on Dec. 11 at the National Gallery of Victoria in Australia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei at the unveiling of his sculpture "Forever" outside the Gherkin building in London on Sept. 16.

item.title: Letter From Washington: How Trump Has Upended the Story Line
item.description: Reflecting the populist drift of the far right of the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has deftly played into the central fears of many voters.
item.dc:creator: ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Bangladeshi Officials Say 4 Arrested in Killing of Italian Aid Worker Were Not With ISIS
item.description: The authorities dismissed claims that the Islamic State was behind a fatal shooting in Dhaka last month, saying the motive was to “keep the government under pressure.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Poachers’ Cyanide Kills 22 Elephants in Park
item.description: The Zimbabwe Parks and Wildlife Management Authority said poachers had gotten away with three ivory tusks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Former Official Pleads Not Guilty in Corruption Case
item.description: The former national security adviser made the plea in connection with $423,000 in Nigerian and United States currency seized at his homes.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
